info.game_comments: (Sofia: I'm Sofia of the Clue Crew.  You don't have to be a rocket scientist to be on Jeopardy!, but you do if you want to work here.  Jeopardy!'s next.)

(1, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew is at the JPL in Pasadena.)  The inflatable rover, in action here, was designed like the Sojourner rover to crawl over this planet

(2, 1).clue: The first road constructed in this state after the Europeans arrived was along the Rio Grande

(4, 1).clue: Boosting membership to 54, Afghanistan, Iceland & Sweden all joined this organization on November 11, 1946

(5, 1).clue: It's what you're doing when you're "cutting a rug"

(6, 1).clue: Last name of 2 presidents, or a small cluster of shrubs appearing as a single plant

(1, 2).clue: JPL spacecraft have visited every planet in our solar system except this one

(2, 2).clue: This country's North Island is on the Australian Continental Plate; South Island is on the Pacific Plate

(4, 2).clue: Now docked in Long Beach, CA. this ship docked in New York on February 10, 1946 with 1,666 British war brides aboard

(5, 2).clue: Ecclesiastes says, "A man hath no better thing under the sun than to eat, and to drink and to be" this

(6, 2).clue: The little sister of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, or Tony Orlando's backup singers

(1, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from the JPL in Pasadena.)  The thermal vacuum chamber can cool to 5 degrees Kelvin, which is 5 above this hypothetical point

(2, 3).clue: Once the capital of New Netherland, New York City was originally named this

(4, 3).clue: This former first lady suffered minor injuries when she crashed her car in Yonkers, N.Y. on August 14, 1946

(5, 3).clue: You've let loose when this animal precedes "around" or "play"

(6, 3).clue: "I'm gonna live forever...light up the sky like a flame...baby remember my name" & also this tune

(1, 4).clue: JPL was transferred from Army control in 1958 to this newly created government agency

(2, 4).clue: It was the first American colony to declare its independence from Great Britain in 1776

(4, 4).clue: In 1946 this dictator said the world was divided into "two camps" & war was inevitable while capitalism existed

(5, 4).clue: Spelled one way, it's to have casino fun; spelled another, it's delightful skipping

(6, 4).clue: It's a still, deep place in a stream; I lost $5 in our office one for the Super Bowl

(1, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from the JPL in Pasadena.)  Scientists at JPL are learning to navigate a vessel close to this type of celestial body, Latin for "long-haired star"

(2, 5).clue: This Connecticut city, one of the first planned communities, was also the first to have antipoverty programs, in 1962

(4, 5).clue: This 50-year-old ex-colonel was elected president of Argentina on March 28, 1946

(5, 5).clue: Fancy, as in what's tickled when you are amused, is a shortened form of this word

(6, 5).clue: Old English for "to stuff", it's what you might have done late last night before your appearance here

(1, 1).clue: While growing up, one of Tim McGraw's heroes was this ballplayer whom he later learned was his father

(2, 1).clue: There are little brown & big brown species of this winged cave dweller

(3, 1).clue: At Oxford, to be "sent" in this direction is to be expelled

(4, 1).clue: The constellation Crux points to this pole

(5, 1).clue: This gem seen here got its name because of its pomegranate-like color

(6, 1).clue: One can hold hunters, caretakers or beavers

(1, 2).clue: While Faith Hill hails from Mississippi, Tim McGraw grew up in Richland Parish in this state

(2, 2).clue: 3-letter term for a little brown young member of Ursus arctos

(3, 2).clue: The ceremony called Encaenia awards this type of degree, as in 2000 to Judi Dench

(4, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from the Santa Monica Pier.)  These planes named after their wing configurations were flown by the Wright Bros. but disappeared after World War II

(5, 2).clue: Because she ate his pomegranate seeds, Persephone had to return to his underground home for 4 months every year

(6, 2).clue: Often having a veranda, this single-storied, gable-roofed cozy little house is "of Bengal"

(1, 3).clue: Let it out nice & slow... it's the name of Faith's No. 1 album that includes the hit "The Way You Love Me"

(2, 3).clue: This small "nutty" bird may be red-breasted, white-breasted or brown-headed

(3, 3).clue: This is the usual word that combines the names of Oxford & its main rival

(4, 3).clue: He experimented with prisms & published his theories on light & color in 1704's "Opticks"

(5, 3).clue: Pomegranate syrup is sold under this name

(6, 3).clue: A small house by the lake known for its "cheese" or "industry"

(1, 4).clue: Tim & Faith kindled their relationship during this 1995 concert tour; it also means to catch fire without an outside source

(2, 4).clue: This small rodent whose name rhymes with mole is closely related to the lemming

(3, 4).clue: Oxonians do it in a flat-bottomed boat in summer term; across the pond we do it on fourth down

(4, 4).clue: Jan Van Riebeeck led the first European settlement of what would become this South African seaport

(5, 4).clue: "Madonna of the Pomegranate" is one of the many Madonnas in the Uffizi by this "Venus on the Half Shell" artist

(6, 4).clue: From the name of a hill in Rome, it's an official residence of a ruler or archbishop

(2, 5).clue: This small mouselike animal makes up the largest family among the insectivores

(4, 5).clue: The Mayflower had to return to port twice because of this leaky companion ship, then left it behind

(6, 5).clue: John Patrick's post-WWII comedy was this "of the August Moon"

(0, 0).clue: In 1935 she sent a telegram to a Macmillan editor: "Please send manuscript back I've changed my mind"
